text:
Russian President Vladimir Putin says he has 
control after a brief rebellion by a mercenary

group, and South Carolina's Supreme Court will 
hear a challenge today at the state's six-week

abortion ban. Good morning, I'm Korva Coleman 
from NPR News and here are today's top stories.

Russian President Vladimir Putin 
is re-establishing control over his

country. He gave a speech late last night. This 
follows a short-lived rebellion by the mercenary

Wagner Group that lasted a day and ended when 
Wagner founder Yevgeny Prigozhin agreed to go

into exile in neighboring Belarus. NPR's Charles 
Maynes says it's not quite clear if Prigozhin is

there yet. Belarusian media today reported that a 
plane believed to be used by Prigozhin landed in

Minsk the capital of Belarus this morning. 
Also Russia's Federal Security Services,

the FSB, announced this morning they dropped 
this Insurrection charge against Prigozhin

and the rest of the Wagner Fighters. The 
question now seems to be whether Prigozhin

will keep his end of whatever bargain he made 
with Putin. NPR's Charles Maynes reporting.

Forecasters are warning of dangerous heat 
in many southern states today from Arizona

to Florida. The National Weather Service 
has issued excessive heat watches from

southern Illinois to parts of Alabama. 
Heat indices could reach 115 degrees.

South Carolina's Supreme Court will hear a 
challenge of the state's six-week abortion ban

today. This will be the second time a law severely 
restricting the procedure comes before the court.

South Carolina Public Radio's Maayan Schechter has 
more. Lawyers for GOP leaders will be back at the

state's high court to defend the latest effort by 
legislators to impose strict limits on abortion.

The question before the five justices: is the 
law passed this year substantially different

from a six-week ban passed in 2021 that the state 
Supreme Court ruled unconstitutional in January?

In May, South Carolina's two abortion providers 
sued the state after Governor Henry McMaster

signed a law prohibiting abortions with limited 
exceptions once cardiac activity is detected,
typically around six weeks of pregnancy.

GOP leaders believe the new ban fixes concerns 
raised in the Court's January opinion.
For NPR news I'm Maayan Schechter in Colombia.

Prosecutors in Idaho will seek the death 
penalty for Bryan Kohberger . From Northwest

Public Broadcasting, Lauren Paterson reports 
Kohbergerr is the suspect in the killings of

four University of Idaho students. New documents 
filed by the Latah County prosecutor's office say

the circumstances of the murders meet multiple 
Idaho codes for pursuing the death penalty for

Kohbergerr. Reasons listed include multiple 
murders, a quote "disregard for human life",

and that the crime was especially heinous and 
cruel. All of the victims were stabbed to death.

The victims in the case were Kaylee 
Goncalves, Madison Mogen, Ethan Chapin,

and Xana Kernodle. At the time of his arrest 
in December, 28-year-old Kohbergerr was a

graduate student at neighboring Washington 
State University studying criminology.

For NPR News, I'm Lauren 
Paterson in Moscow, Idaho.
You're listening to NPR news
